Founded in 1869, Goldman Sachs is headquartered at [[200 West Street]] in [[Lower Manhattan]], with regional [[headquarters]] in [[London]], [[Warsaw]], [[Bangalore]], [[Hong Kong]], [[Tokyo]], [[Dallas]] and [[Salt Lake City]], and additional offices in other international financial centers.{{cite web |url=https://www.goldmansachs.com/our-firm/locations.html |title=Goldman Sachs - Our Firm |website=Goldman Sachs |archive-date=February 26, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190226234123/https://www.goldmansachs.com/our-firm/locations.html |url-status=live}} Goldman Sachs is the [[list of investment banks|second largest investment bank]] in the world by revenue{{Cite web |url=https://www.statista.com/statistics/371143/leading-global-investment-banks-by-revenue/ |title=Leading banks worldwide, by revenue from investment banking |website=[[Statista]] |url-status=live}} and is ranked 57th on the [[Fortune 500]] list of the largest United States corporations by total revenue.{{cite web | url=https://fortune.com/company/goldman-sachs-group/fortune500/ | title=Fortune 500 Companies: Goldman Sachs | publisher=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] | url-status=live }} It is considered a [[systemically important financial institution]] by the [[Financial Stability Board]]. The company has been criticized for a lack of ethical standards, working with dictatorial regimes,{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-02-06/goldman-sachs-shouldn-t-work-for-russia-human-rights-group-says| title=Goldman Sachs Shouldn't Work for Russia, Human Rights Group Says |last=Harper |first=Christine | work=[[Bloomberg News]] |date=February 6, 2013 | url-access=subscription |archive-date=February 26, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170226201216/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-02-06/goldman-sachs-shouldn-t-work-for-russia-human-rights-group-says |url-status=live}} close relationships with the U.S. federal government via a "[[Revolving door (politics)|revolving door]]" of former employees,{{cite news|last1=Creswell |first1=Julie |last2=White |first2=Ben |title=The Guys From 'Government Sachs' |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/19/business/19gold.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 17, 2008 | url-access=limited |archive-date=February 20, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140220160810/http://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/19/business/19gold.html |url-status=live}} and driving up prices of [[Commodity market|commodities]] through [[Futures exchange|futures]] speculation. While the company has appeared on the [[100 Best Companies to Work For]] list compiled by ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'', primarily due to its high compensation levels,{{cite news | url=https://fortune.com/best-companies/2020/goldman-sachs-group/ | title=100 Best Companies to Work | publisher=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]}}{{cite news | url=https://www.greatplacetowork.com/certified-company/1000101 | title=Goldman Sachs Group - Best Companies to Work | archive-date=May 17, 2017 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170517124059/http://reviews.greatplacetowork.com/goldman-sachs | url-status=live}} it has also been criticized by its employees for 100-hour work weeks, high levels of employee dissatisfaction among first-year analysts, abusive treatment by superiors, a lack of mental health resources, and extremely high levels of stress in the workplace leading to physical discomfort.{{Cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/19/business/goldman-sachs-analysts-workplace-complaint.html | title='I'm in a really dark place': Complaints at Goldman Sachs set off a workplace debate. |last1=Karaian |first1=Jason |last2=Sorkin | first2=Andrew Ross | author-link1=Andrew Ross Sorkin | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=March 19, 2021 | url-access=limited | issn=0362-4331 |archive-date=September 16, 2021 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210916055629/https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/19/business/goldman-sachs-analysts-workplace-complaint.html |url-status=live}}{{Cite news |last=Ghosh|first=Palash|title=Goldman Sachs First-Year Analysts Face 100-Hour Weeks, Abusive Behavior, Stress: Survey Says|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/palashghosh/2021/03/18/goldman-sachs-first-year-analysts-face-100-hour-weeks-abusive-behavior-stress-survey-says/|access-date=September 16, 2021|website=Forbes|language=en|archive-date=September 16, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210916055628/https://www.forbes.com/sites/palashghosh/2021/03/18/goldman-sachs-first-year-analysts-face-100-hour-weeks-abusive-behavior-stress-survey-says/|url-status=live}} The company invests in and arranges financing for startups, and in many cases gets additional business when the companies launch [[initial public offering]]s.{{Cite news | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/goldman-sachs-wants-to-charm-startups-it-wont-be-easy-11621515741 | title=Goldman Sachs Wants to Charm Startups. Forum]] |language=en}} ==History== ===Founding and establishment === {{See also|Goldman–Sachs family}} Goldman Sachs was founded in New York City in 1869 by [[Marcus Goldman]].{{cite news | first1=Leah Nathans | last1=Spiro | first2=Stanley | last2=Reed | title=Inside the Money Machine-In a big-is-all business, Goldman vows to go it alone | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/1997-12-21/inside-the-money-machine | publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.]] | date=December 22, 1997 | access-date=April 7, 2017 | archive-date=August 27, 2020 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200827190404/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/1997-12-21/inside-the-money-machine | url-status=live }} In 1882, Goldman's son-in-law [[Samuel Sachs]] joined the firm.{{cite news | url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,770464,00.html | title=Business & Finance: Cash & Comeback | magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] | date=November 9, 1936 | url-access=subscription | access-date=March 19, 2017 | archive-date=October 23, 2020 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201023122152/http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,770464,00.html | url-status=live }}{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/2010/05/21/goldman-sachs-fraud-case-personal-finance-gs.html#1b2ef41476b3|title=The Evolution Of Goldman Sachs|last=Beattie|first=Andrew|website=Forbes|language=en|access-date=February 11, 2020|archive-date=July 22, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180722160258/https://www.forbes.com/2010/05/21/goldman-sachs-fraud-case-personal-finance-gs.html#1b2ef41476b3|url-status=live}} In 1885, Goldman took his son Henry and his son-in-law Ludwig Dreyfuss into the business and the firm adopted its present name, Goldman Sachs & Co.{{Cite book|last=Endlich|first=Lisa|author-link=Lisa Endlich|title=Goldman Sachs: The Culture Of Success|publisher=[[A.A. Knopf]]|location=New York|year=1999|isbn=978-0-679-45080-1|page=[https://archive.org/details/goldmansachscult00endl/page/34 34]|url=https://archive.org/details/goldmansachscult00endl/page/34}} The company pioneered the use of [[commercial paper]] for entrepreneurs and joined the [[New York Stock Exchange]] (NYSE) in 1896.{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=91XpjbCqbbcC | author=William D. Cohan | title=Money and Power: How Goldman Sachs Came to Rule the World | year=2012 | publisher=[[Penguin Random House]] | isbn=978-0-241-95406-5 | access-date=May 9, 2017 | archive-date=March 31, 2019 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190331160518/https://books.google.com/books?id=91XpjbCqbbcC | url-status=live }} By 1898, the firm's capital stood at $1.6 million. Goldman entered the [[initial public offering]] market in 1906 when it took [[Sears, Roebuck and Company]] public. The deal was facilitated by Henry Goldman's personal friendship with [[Julius Rosenwald]], an owner of Sears. Other IPOs followed, including [[F. W. Woolworth Company|F. W. Woolworth]] and [[Continental Can]]. In 1912, Henry S. Bowers became the first non-member of the founding family to become a partner of the company and share in its profits. In 1917, under growing pressure from the other partners in the firm due to his pro-German stance, Henry Goldman resigned. The Sachs family gained full control of the firm until [[Waddill Catchings]] joined the company in 1918. By 1928, Catchings was the Goldman partner with the single largest stake in the firm. On December 4, 1928, the firm launched the Goldman Sachs Trading Corp, a [[closed-end fund]].{{Cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/photo-essays/2011-07-20/goldman-sachs-the-good-the-bad-and-the-ugly |title=Goldman Sachs, the Good, the Bad, and the Ugly |work=[[Bloomberg News]] |date=July 20, 2011 | url-access=subscription | archive-date=March 31, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190331104330/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/photo-essays/2011-07-20/goldman-sachs-the-good-the-bad-and-the-ugly|url-status=live}} The fund failed during the [[Stock Market Crash of 1929]], amid accusations that Goldman had engaged in share price manipulation and [[insider trading]]. ===Mid-20th century=== In 1930, the firm ousted Catchings, and [[Sidney Weinberg]] assumed the role of senior partner and shifted Goldman's focus away from trading and toward [[investment banking]]. Weinberg's actions helped to restore some of Goldman's tarnished reputation. Under Weinberg's leadership, Goldman was the lead advisor on the [[Ford Motor Company]]'s IPO in 1956, a major coup on Wall Street at the time. Under Weinberg's reign, the firm started an investment research division and a [[municipal bond]] department, and it became an early innovator in [[risk arbitrage]]. In the 1950s, [[Gus Levy]] joined the firm as a securities trader, where two powers fought for supremacy, one from investment banking and one from securities trading. Levy was a pioneer in [[block trade|block trading]] and the firm established this trend under his guidance. Due to Weinberg's heavy influence, the firm formed an investment banking division in 1956 in an attempt to shift focus off Weinberg. In 1957, the company's headquarters were relocated to 20 [[Broad Street (Manhattan)|Broad Street]], New York City. In 1969, Levy took over Weinberg's role as Senior Partner and built Goldman's trading franchise once again.{{Cite book|last=Endlich|first=Lisa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BDionNrrBqwC&q=1969+levy&pg=PA62|title=Goldman Sachs: The Culture Of Success|date=March 9, 2000|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=978-0-684-86968-1|pages=62|language=en|access-date=October 21, 2020|archive-date=June 14, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210614103756/https://books.google.com/books?id=BDionNrrBqwC&q=1969+levy&pg=PA62|url-status=live}} Levy is credited with Goldman's famous philosophy of being "long-term greedy," which implied that as long as money is made over the long term, short-term losses are bearable. At the same time, partners reinvested nearly all of their earnings in the firm.{{Cite book|last=Endlich|first=Lisa|author-link=Lisa Endlich|title=Goldman Sachs: The Culture Of Success|publisher=[[A.A. Knopf]]|location=New York|year=1999|isbn=978-0-679-45080-1|page=[https://archive.org/details/goldmansachscult00endl/page/18 18]|url=https://archive.org/details/goldmansachscult00endl/page/18}} Weinberg remained a senior partner of the firm and died in July of that year.{{cite web |url=https://www.goldmansachs.com/our-firm/history/moments/1930-sidney-weinberg-leads.html |title=Sidney Weinberg Leads the Firm for More than Three Decades |publisher=Goldman Sachs |access-date=July 29, 2021 |url-status=live |archive-date=August 13, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210813111208/https://www.goldmansachs.com/our-firm/history/moments/1930-sidney-weinberg-leads.html }} Another financial crisis for the firm occurred in 1970, when the [[Penn Central Transportation Company]] went bankrupt with over $80 million in [[commercial paper]] outstanding, most of it issued through Goldman Sachs. The bankruptcy was large, and the resulting lawsuits, notably by the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|SEC]], threatened the partnership capital, survival, and reputation of the firm.{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/goldman-sachss-long-history-of-duping-its-clients/2012/03/15/gIQAVlu3GS_story.html | title=Goldman Sachs's long history of duping its clients | last=Cohan | first=William D. | newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] | date=March 16, 2012 | url-access=limited | archive-date=November 9, 2020 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201109190908/https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/goldman-sachss-long-history-of-duping-its-clients/2012/03/15/gIQAVlu3GS_story.html | url-status=live }} It was this bankruptcy that resulted in [[credit rating]]s for every issuer of commercial paper today by several credit rating services.{{cite web | last=Hahn | first=Thomas K. | editor=Timothy Q. Cook | editor2=Robert K. Laroche | title=Instruments of the Money Market | url=https://www.richmondfed.org/~/media/richmondfedorg/publications/research/special_reports/instruments_of_the_money_market/pdf/full_publication.pdf | edition=Seventh | publisher=Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond | location=[[Richmond, Virginia]] | year=1993 | access-date=April 7, 2017 | archive-date=November 25, 2020 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201125001943/https://www.richmondfed.org/~/media/richmondfedorg/publications/research/special_reports/instruments_of_the_money_market/pdf/full_publication.pdf | url-status=live }} Under the direction of Senior Partner Stanley R. Miller, the firm opened its first international office in London in 1970 and created a [[Private Wealth Management]] division along with a [[fixed income]] division in 1972.{{Cite news |last=Colchester |first=Max |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/who-loses-the-most-from-brexit-try-goldman-sachs-1460403274 |title=Who Loses the Most From 'Brexit'? Try Goldman Sachs |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=April 11, 2016 |issn=0099-9660 |archive-date=November 8, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201108095658/https://www.wsj.com/articles/who-loses-the-most-from-brexit-try-goldman-sachs-1460403274|url-status=live}} It pioneered the "[[white knight (business)|white knight]]" strategy in 1974 during its attempts to defend Electric Storage Battery against a [[hostile takeover]] bid from International Nickel and Goldman's rival, [[Morgan Stanley]].{{cite book | first=Gary | last=Giroux | title=Accounting Fraud: Maneuvering and Manipulation, Past and Present | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gxNMAgAAQBAJ | publisher=Business Expert Press | isbn=9781606496299 | date=December 9, 2013 | archive-date=April 8, 2017 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170408085303/https://books.google.com/books?id=gxNMAgAAQBAJ | url-status=live }} [[John Weinberg|John L. Weinberg]] (the son of Sidney Weinberg), and [[John C. Whitehead]] assumed roles of co-senior partners in 1976, once again emphasizing the co-leadership at the firm. One of their initiatives was the establishment of 14 business principles that the firm still claims to apply.{{Cite news |last=Thomas |first=Landon Jr. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/09/business/09weinberg.html |title=John L. Weinberg, 81, Former Leader of Goldman, Dies |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=August 9, 2006 | url-access=limited |issn=0362-4331 |archive-date=November 21, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201121075533/https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/09/business/09weinberg.html |url-status=live}} ===Late 20th century=== On November 16, 1981, the firm acquired J. Aron & Company, a [[commodities trading]] firm which merged with the Fixed Income division to become known as Fixed Income, Currencies, and Commodities.{{Cite news |last=Baer |first=Justin |title=In Wake of Financial Crisis, Goldman Goes It Alone |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/in-wake-of-financial-crisis-goldman-goes-it-alone-1423711981|date=December 12, 2015 | url-access=subscription |issn=0099-9660|archive-date=August 1, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200801042635/https://www.wsj.com/articles/in-wake-of-financial-crisis-goldman-goes-it-alone-1423711981 |url-status=live}} J. Aron was involved in the coffee and gold markets, and the former CEO of Goldman, [[Lloyd Blankfein]], joined the firm as a result of this merger.{{Cite news |title=As rivals fade, Goldman Sachs stands firm on commodities |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2013/12/06/as-rivals-fade-goldman-sachs-stands-firm-on-commodities.html |work=[[CNBC]] |date=December 6, 2013|archive-date=November 29, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201129115336/https://www.cnbc.com/2013/12/06/as-rivals-fade-goldman-sachs-stands-firm-on-commodities.html|url-status=live}} In 1985, it underwrote the public offering of the [[real estate investment trust]] that owned [[Rockefeller Center]], then the largest [[Real estate investment trust|REIT]] offering in history.{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/business/1995/09/19/pitching-them-high-and-inside-in-the-rockefeller-center-deal/7794b49c-3489-448e-a33c-4d8a691034f6/ |last=Sloan |first=Allan | author-link=Allan Sloan |title=PITCHING THEM HIGH AND INSIDE IN THE ROCKEFELLER CENTER DEAL | newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=September 19, 1995 |issn=0190-8286 |archive-date=February 8, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210208043020/https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/business/1995/09/19/pitching-them-high-and-inside-in-the-rockefeller-center-deal/7794b49c-3489-448e-a33c-4d8a691034f6/|url-status=live}} In accordance with the beginning of the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]], the firm also became involved in facilitating the global privatization movement by advising companies that were spinning off from their parent governments.{{Cite web | last=McCoy| first=Patricia |title=Levers of Law Reform: Public Goods and Russian Banking | url=https://scholarship.law.cornell.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1395&context=cilj | publisher=[[Cornell Law School]] | year=1997 | archive-date=October 22, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201022190041/https://scholarship.law.cornell.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1395&context=cilj |url-status=live}} In 1986, the firm formed Goldman Sachs Asset Management, which manages the majority of its mutual funds and [[hedge fund]]s. In the same year, the firm also underwrote the IPO of [[Microsoft]], advised [[General Electric]] on its acquisition of [[RCA]],{{Cite news | title=Goldman Sachs humbled | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/analysis-and-features/goldman-sachs-humbled-1192852.html | work=[[The Independent]] | date=December 17, 2008 | archive-date=November 16, 2020 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201116055405/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/analysis-and-features/goldman-sachs-humbled-1192852.html | url-status=live}} joined the [[London Stock Exchange|London]] and [[Tokyo stock exchange]]s, and became the first United States bank to rank in the top 10 of [[mergers and acquisitions]] in the United Kingdom.{{citation needed|date=October 2020}} During the 1980s, the firm became the first bank to distribute its investment research electronically and created the first public offering of original issue deep-discount [[bond (finance)|bond]]. [[Robert Rubin]] and [[Stephen Friedman (PFIAB)|Stephen Friedman]] assumed the co-senior partnership in 1990 and pledged to focus on globalization of the firm to strengthen the merger & acquisition and trading business lines.{{Cite news|date=April 4, 2013|title=Former Goldman head Stephen Friedman retires from board|language=en|work=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-goldman-board-idUSBRE93315P20130404|access-date=August 13, 2020|archive-date=November 3, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201103184956/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-goldman-board-idUSBRE93315P20130404|url-status=live}} During their tenure as co-senior partners, the firm So let's reduce this macro story to human scale. Meet GSAMP Trust 2006-S3, a $494 million drop in the junk-mortgage bucket, part of the more than half-a-trillion dollars of mortgage-backed securities issued last year. We found this issue by asking mortgage mavens to pick the worst deal they knew of that had been floated by a top-tier firm - and this one's pretty bad. It was sold by Goldman Sachs - GSAMP originally stood for Goldman Sachs Alternative Mortgage Products but now has become a name itself, like [[AT&T Inc.|AT&T]] and [[3M]]. This issue, which is backed by ultra-risky second-mortgage loans, contains all the elements that facilitated the housing bubble and bust. It's got speculators searching for quick gains in hot housing markets; it's got loans that seem to have been made with little or no serious analysis by lenders; and finally, it's got Wall Street, which churned out mortgage "product" because buyers wanted it. As they say on the Street, "When the ducks quack, feed them."

Freeman]], who was a senior Partner, who was the Head of Risk Arbitrage, and who was a protégé of [[Robert Rubin]], pleaded guilty to [[insider trading]], for his own account and for the firm's account.{{cite news |first=Landon Jr. |last=Thomas |title=Cold Call |url=http://nymag.com/nymetro/news/bizfinance/columns/businessclass/5693/ |work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] |date=February 18, 2002 |access-date=January 17, 2007 |archive-date=April 1, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070401075557/http://nymag.com/nymetro/news/bizfinance/columns/businessclass/5693/ |url-status=live }} ====Rajat Gupta insider trading case==== {{Main|Raj Rajaratnam/Galleon Group, Anil Kumar, and Rajat Gupta insider trading cases}} [[File:Rajat Kumar Gupta - World Economic Forum Annual Meeting Davos 2010 crop.jpg|thumb|Rajat Gupta]] In April 2010, Goldman director [[Rajat Gupta]] was named in an insider-trading case. In early 2011, with the delayed Rajaratnam criminal trial about to begin,{{cite news|last1=McCool|first1=Grant|last2=McCormick|first2=Gerald|title=Judge postpones Rajaratnam trial to March 8|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-galleon-rajaratnam-idUSTRE7193V120110210|access-date=March 1, 2011|agency=Thompson Reuters|issue=Business News|publisher=Reuters|date=February 10, 2011|location=New York, N.Y., United States|language=en|archive-date=January 5, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160105233438/http://www.reuters.com/article/us-galleon-rajaratnam-idUSTRE7193V120110210|url-status=live}} the [[United States Securities and Exchange Commission]] (SEC) announced civil charges against Gupta covering the Berkshire investment as well as confidential quarterly earnings information from Goldman and [[Procter & Gamble]] (P&G). He was also a board member of [[AMR Corporation]].{{cite news | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2011-10-26/ex-goldman-sachs-director-gupta-said-to-face-insider-trading-probe-charges | title=Ex-Goldman Director Gupta Indicted in Probe of Rajaratnam Trades | first1=Patricia | last1=Hurtado | first2=David | last2=Glovin | first3=Chris | last3=Dolmetsch | work=[[Bloomberg News]] | date=November 11, 2014 | url-access=subscription | access-date=May 16, 2017 | archive-date=November 20, 2017 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171120203237/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2011-10-26/ex-goldman-sachs-director-gupta-said-to-face-insider-trading-probe-charges | url-status=live }} Gupta was convicted in June 2012 on [[insider trading]] charges stemming from [[Raj Rajaratnam/Galleon Group, Anil Kumar, and Rajat Gupta insider trading cases|Galleon Group case]] on [[#Insider trading conviction|four criminal felony counts]] of [[conspiracy (crime)|conspiracy]] and [[securities fraud]]. He was sentenced in October 2012 to two years in prison, an additional year on supervised release and ordered to pay $5 million in fines.{{cite news | url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/oct/24/business/la-fi-mo-gupta-sentenced-20121024 | title=Rajat Gupta, former Goldman Sachs director, is sentenced | first=Andrew | last=Tangel | work=[[Los Angeles Times]] | date=October 24, 2012 | access-date=May 16, 2017 | archive-date=April 15, 2016 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160415052216/http://articles.latimes.com/2012/oct/24/business/la-fi-mo-gupta-sentenced-20121024 | url-status=live }} ===Abacus synthetic CDOs and SEC lawsuit === {{anchor|Abacus CDO}} {{See also|Merrill Lynch#CDO controversies|Magnetar Capital}} Unlike many investors and investment bankers, Goldman Sachs anticipated the [[subprime mortgage crisis]] that developed in 2007-8.{{cite news|last1=Morgenson|first1=Gretchen|last2=Story|first2=Louise|title=Banks Bundled Bad Debt, Bet Against It and Won|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/24/business/24trading.html|access-date=April 14, 2010|agency=The New York Times Company|issue=Business|page=A1|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=December 24, 2009|location=New York, N.Y., United States|language=en|url-access=limited|archive-date=April 30, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110430022305/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/24/business/24trading.html|url-status=live}} ''This article describes the intricate links between Goldman Sachs trader, Jonathan M. Egol, synthetic collateralized debt obligations, or C.D.O., ABACUS, and asset-backed securities index (ABX)'' Some of its traders became "bearish" on the housing boom beginning in 2004 and developed mortgage-related securities, originally intended to protect Goldman from investment losses in the housing market. In late 2006, Goldman management changed the firm's overall stance on the mortgage market from positive to negative. As the market began its downturn, Goldman "created even more of these securities", no longer just hedging or satisfying investor orders but, according to business journalist Gretchen Morgenson, "enabling it to pocket huge profits" from the mortgage defaults and that Goldman "used the C.D.O.'s to place unusually large negative bets that were not mainly for hedging purposes". Authors Bethany McLean and Joe Nocera stated that "the firm's later insistence that it was merely a 'market maker' in these transactions - implying that it had no stake in the economic performance of the securities it was selling to clients - became less true over time"-{{cite book | author=McLean and Nocera | title=All the Devils Are Here | page=271}} The investments were called [[synthetic CDO]]s because unlike regular [[collateralized debt obligation]]s, the principal and interest they paid out came not from mortgages or other loans, but from premiums to pay for insurance against mortgage defaults - the insurance known as "[[credit default swap]]s". Goldman and some other hedge funds held a "short" position in the securities, paying the premiums, while the investors (insurance companies, pension funds, etc.) receiving the premiums were the "long" position. The longs were responsible for paying the insurance "claim" to Goldman and any other shorts if the mortgages or other loans defaulted. Through April 2007, Goldman issued over 20 CDOs in its "Abacus" series worth a total of $10.9 billion.{{cite news|last1=Story|first1=Louise|last2=Morgenson|first2=Gretchen|title=S.E.C. Accuses Goldman of Fraud in Housing Deal|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/17/business/17goldman.html|access-date=January 26, 2014|agency=The New York Times Company|issue=Business|page=A1|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=April 16, 2010|location=New York, N.Y., United States|language=en|url-access=limited|archive-date=December 22, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131222223130/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/17/business/17goldman.html|url-status=live}} All together Goldman packaged, sold, and shorted a total of 47 synthetic CDOs, with an aggregate face value of $66 billion between July 1, 2004, and May 31, 2007.''FCIR'' p.145 But while Goldman was praised for its foresight, some argued its bets against the securities it created gave it a vested interest in their failure. These securities performed very poorly for the long investors and by April 2010, at least US$5 billion worth of the securities either carried "junk" ratings or had defaulted.{{cite news | url=http://www.smh.com.au/business/world-business/abacus-let-goldman-shuffle-mortgage-risk-like-beads-20100418-smx3.html | title=Abacus Let Goldman Shuffle Mortgage Risk Like Beads | first1=Jody | last1=Shenn | first2=Bob | last2=Ivry | agency=[[Bloomberg News]] | publisher=[[Sydney Morning Herald]] | date=April 16, 2010 | access-date=May 21, 2017 | archive-date=November 8, 2021 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211108131217/https://www.smh.com.au/business/abacus-let-goldman-shuffle-mortgage-risk-like-beads-20100419-smx3.html | url-status=live }} One CDO examined by critics which Goldman bet against but also sold to investors, was the $800 million Hudson Mezzanine CDO issued in 2006. In the Senate Permanent Subcommittee hearings, Goldman executives stated that the company was trying to remove subprime securities from its books. Unable to sell them directly, it included them in the underlying securities of the CDO and took the short side, but critics McLean and Nocera complained the CDO prospectus did not explain this but described its contents as "'assets sourced from the Street', making it sound as though Goldman randomly selected the securities, instead of specifically creating a hedge for its own book".{{cite book | author1=Bethany McLean | author2=Joe Nocera | title=All the Devils Are Here: The Hidden History of the Financial Crisis |page=274 |quote=The CDO had been constructed, Goldman executives later told the Senate Permanent Subcommittee, while the company was trying to remove triple-B assets from its books. Among those assets was a long position in the ABX index that Goldman had gotten 'stuck' with while putting together deals for hedge fund clients that wanted to go short. Unable to find counterparties to take the long position off its hands, Goldman used Hudson as a means by which it hedged its long position. ... None of which was clear from the Hudson prospectus. Instead, the disclosure merely said that the CDO's contents were 'assets sourced from the Street', making it sound as though Goldman randomly selected the securities, instead of specifically creating a hedge for its won book.}} The CDO did not perform well, and by March 2008 - just 18 months after its issue - so many borrowers had defaulted that holders of the security paid out "about US$310 million to Goldman and others who had bet against it". Goldman's head of European fixed-income sales lamented in an e-mail made public by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, the "real bad feeling across European sales about some of the trades we did with clients" who had invested in the CDO. "The damage this has done to our franchise is very significant."{{cite book | author1=Bethany McLean | author2=Joe Nocera | title=All the Devils Are Here: The Hidden History of the Financial Crisis | page=274}} ====2010 SEC civil fraud lawsuit==== In April 2010, the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] (SEC) charged Goldman Sachs and one of its vice-presidents, Fabrice Tourre, with securities fraud. The SEC alleged that Goldman had told buyers of a [[synthetic CDO]], a type of investment, that the underlying assets in the investment had been picked by an independent CDO manager, ACA Management. In fact, [[Paulson & Co.]] a [[hedge fund]] that wanted to bet against the investment had played a "significant role" in the selection,''[http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/GPO-FCIC/pdf/GPO-FCIC.pdf Financial Crisis Inquiry Report] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180906112326/https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/GPO-FCIC/pdf/GPO-FCIC.pdf |date=September 6, 2018 }}'', by the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, 2011, p.192 and the package of securities turned out to become "one of the worst-performing mortgage deals of the housing crisis" because "less than a year after the deal was completed, 100% of the bonds selected for Abacus had been downgraded".{{cite news|last1=Lucchetti|first1=Aaron|last2=Ng|first2=Serena|title=Abacus Deal: As Bad as They Come|journal=The Wall Street Journal. Eastern Edition|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703757504575194521257607284|access-date=February 26, 2014|agency=Dow Jones & Company Inc|issue=Business|publisher=Wall Street Journal|date=April 20, 2010|location=United States|language=en|url-access=subscription|issn=0099-9660|archive-date=March 11, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150311151219/http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703757504575194521257607284|url-status=live}} The particular synthetic CDO that the SEC's 2010 fraud suit charged Goldman with misleading investors with was called Abacus 2007-AC1. Unlike many of the Abacus securities, 2007-AC1 did not have Goldman Sachs as a short seller, in fact, Goldman Sachs lost money on the deal.{{cite web | title=Goldman Sachs and The ABACUS Deal | url=http://sevenpillarsinstitute.org/case-studies/goldman-sachs-and-the-abacus-deal | first1=Philip | last1=Whalen | first2=Kara | last2=Tan Bhala | publisher=[[Seven Pillars Institute]] | access-date=February 27, 2014 | archive-date=March 6, 2014 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140306214617/http://sevenpillarsinstitute.org/case-studies/goldman-sachs-and-the-abacus-deal | url-status=live }} That position was taken by the customer ([[John Paulson]]) who hired Goldman to issue the security (according to the SEC's complaint). Paulson and his employees selected 90 BBB-rated mortgage bonds{{cite news|last1=Wilchins|first1=Dan|last2=Brettell|first2=Karen|title=Factbox: How Goldman's ABACUS deal worked|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-goldmansachs-abacus-factbox/factbox-how-goldmans-abacus-deal-worked-idUSTRE63F5CZ20100416|access-date=February 9, 2014|agency=Thompson Reuters|issue=Business News|publisher=Reuters|date=April 16, 2010|location=New York, N.Y., United States|language=en|quote=''Hedge fund manager John Paulson tells Goldman Sachs in late 2006 he wants to bet against risky subprime mortgages using derivatives. The risky mortgage bonds that Paulson wanted to short were essentially subprime home loans that had been repackaged into bonds. The bonds were rated "BBB", meaning that as the home loans defaulted, these bonds would be among the first to feel the pain.''|archive-date=September 15, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170915070644/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-goldmansachs-abacus-factbox/factbox-how-goldmans-abacus-deal-worked-idUSTRE63F5CZ20100416|url-status=live}} that they believed were most likely to lose value and so the best bet to buy insurance for. Paulson and the manager of the CDO, ACA Management, worked on the portfolio of 90 bonds to be insured (ACA allegedly unaware of Paulson's short position), coming to an agreement in late February 2007. Paulson paid Goldman approximately US$15 million for its work in the deal.The $15 million has been described as "rent" for the Abacus name.
{{cite book|author1=Bethany McLean |author2=Joe Nocera |title=All the Devils Are Here: The Hidden History of the Financial Crisis |page=279|quote=Paulson knocked on Goldman's door at a fortuitous moment. The firm had begun thinking about 'ABACUS-renal strategies' ... By that, he meant that Goldman would 'rent' - for a hefty fee - the Abacus brand to a hedge fund that wanted to make a massive short bet. ... Paulson paid Goldman $15 million to rent the Abacus name.}} Paulson ultimately made a US$1 billion profit from the short investments, the profits coming from the losses of the investors and their insurers. These were primarily [[IKB Deutsche Industriebank]] (US$150 million loss), and the investors and insurers of another US$900 million - ACA Financial Guaranty Corp,{{cite news|last1=Salmon|first1=Felix|title=Goldman's misleading statement on ACA|url=http://blogs.reuters.com/felix-salmon/2010/04/19/goldmans-misleading-statement-on-aca/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100422005800/http://blogs.reuters.com/felix-salmon/2010/04/19/goldmans-misleading-statement-on-aca/|url-status=dead|archive-date=April 22, 2010|access-date=August 14, 2010|agency=Thompson Reuters|issue=Blogs|publisher=Reuters|date=April 19, 2010|language=en|quote=when Goldman wrapped the super-senior tranche of the Abacus deal, it did so with ABN Amro, a too-big-to-fail bank, and not with ACA. ABN Amro then laid off that risk onto ACA but was on the hook for all of it if ACA went bust. As, of course, it did.}} [[ABN AMRO]], and the [[Royal Bank of Scotland]].{{cite news|last1=Thomas|first1=Landon|title=A Routine Deal Became an $840 Million Mistake|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/23/business/23cdo.html|access-date=February 27, 2014|agency=The New York Times Company|issue=Business|page=A1|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=April 22, 2010|location=New York, N.Y., United States|language=en|url-access=limited|quote=R.B.S. [Royal Bank of Scotland] became involved in Abacus almost by accident. Bankers working in London for ABN Amro, a Dutch bank that was later acquired by R.B.S., agreed to stand behind a portfolio of American mortgage investments that were used in the deal. ABN Amro shouldered almost all of the risks for what, in retrospect, might seem like a small reward: that $7 million. When the housing market fell and Abacus collapsed, R.B.S. ended up on the hook for most of the losses.|archive-date=March 12, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140312081243/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/23/business/23cdo.html|url-status=live}} The SEC alleged that Goldman "materially misstated and omitted facts in disclosure documents" about the financial security, including the fact that it had "permitted a client that was betting against the mortgage market [the hedge fund manager Paulson & Co.] to heavily influence which mortgage securities to include in an investment portfolio, while telling other investors that the securities were selected by an independent, objective third party", ACA Management.{{cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/litigation/complaints/2010/comp21489.pdf|date=April 16, 2010|publisher=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]]|title=Securities and Exchange Commission vs Goldman Sachs & Co & Fabrice Tourre, Complaint (Securities Fraud)|access-date=April 17, 2010|archive-date=May 20, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100520173821/http://www.sec.gov/litigation/complaints/2010/comp21489.pdf|url-status=live}}{{cite press release | url=https://www.sec.gov/news/press/2010/2010-59.htm | title=SEC Charges Goldman Sachs With Fraud in Structuring and Marketing of CDO Tied to Subprime Mortgages | publisher=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] | date=April 16, 2010 | access-date=May 18, 2017 | archive-date=February 14, 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130214105713/http://www.sec.gov/news/press/2010/2010-59.htm | url-status=live }} The SEC further alleged that "Tourre also misled ACA into believing ... that Paulson's interests in the collateral section [sic] process were aligned with ACA's, when, in reality, Paulson's interests were sharply conflicting". When Goldman Sachs management uncovered the trades, Taylor was immediately fired. The trades cost the company $118 million, which Taylor was ordered to repay. In a public letter to the bank’s chief executive, [[Lloyd Blankfein]], the National Assembly president [[Julio Borges]] said that “Goldman Sachs’s financial lifeline to the regime will serve to strengthen the brutal repression unleashed against the hundreds of thousands of Venezuelans peacefully protesting for political change in the country."{{Cite news|last=Rushe|first=Dominic|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/may/30/goldman-sachs-venezuela-bonds|title=Goldman Sachs condemned for buoying Venezuela with $2.8bn bond purchase|date=May 30, 2017|work=The Guardian|access-date=April 13, 2020|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|archive-date=August 1, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200801021421/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/may/30/goldman-sachs-venezuela-bonds|url-status=live}} Sheila Patel, CEO of Goldman Sachs Asset Management’s international division, said in an interview that the incident "turned into a teachable moment within the firm" and "helped sharpen its focus on investing with an eye toward environmental, social and governance policies".{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloombergquint.com/onweb/goldman-says-it-s-learned-from-venezuela-hunger-bonds-backlash|title=Goldman Says It's Learned From Venezuela 'Hunger Bonds' Backlash|website=BloombergQuint|language=en|access-date=April 13, 2020|archive-date=August 1, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200801033125/https://www.bloombergquint.com/onweb/goldman-says-it-s-learned-from-venezuela-hunger-bonds-backlash|url-status=live}} === Work culture === In 2021, Goldman faced scrutiny after a group of first year bankers told managers that they are working 100 hours a week with 5 hours sleep at night. They also said that they have been constantly experiencing workplace abuse that has seriously affected their mental health. In May 2022, Goldman Sachs announced that they would be implementing a more flexible vacation policy to help their employees 'rest and recharge' where they give senior bankers unlimited vacation days, and all employees are expected to have a minimum of 15 days vacation every year.{{Cite web |author=Allison Morrow |title=Goldman Sachs gives top bankers unlimited vacation days |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/05/16/investing/goldman-sachs-unlimited-vacation/index.html |access-date=May 17, 2022 |website=CNN|date=May 16, 2022 }} ==Political contributions== Goldman Sachs employees have donated to both major American political parties, as well as candidates and [[super PAC]]s belonging to both parties. According to [[OpenSecrets]], Goldman Sachs and its employees collectively gave $4.7 million in the [[2014 United States elections|2014 elections]] to various candidates, [[leadership PAC]]s, political parties, [[527 group]]s, and outside spending entities.[https://www.opensecrets.org/orgs/summary.php?id=d000000085 Goldman Sachs: Profile for 2014 Election Cycle] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160908232011/http://www.opensecrets.org/orgs/summary.php?id=D000000085 |date=September 8, 2016 }}, [[OpenSecrets]]. In 2010, the [[Securities and Exchange Commission]] issued regulations that limit asset managers' donations to state and local officials, and prohibit certain top-level employees from donating to such officials.{{cite news|last1=Gillespie|first1=Patrick|title=Goldman Sachs' top 1% employees can't donate to Trump|url=https://money.cnn.com/2016/09/06/investing/goldman-sachs-political-donations/|access-date=September 7, 2016|work=CNNMoney|date=September 6, 2016|archive-date=September 7, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160907140323/http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/06/investing/goldman-sachs-political-donations/|url-status=live}}Sara Sjolin, [http://www.marketwatch.com/story/goldman-sachs-bans-top-staff-from-donating-to-trump-reports-2016-09-07-91031857 Why Goldman Sachs staff can donate to Hillary Clinton but not Donald Trump] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160908182045/http://www.marketwatch.com/story/goldman-sachs-bans-top-staff-from-donating-to-trump-reports-2016-09-07-91031857 |date=September 8, 2016 }}, ''MarketWatch'' (September 7, 2016). This SEC regulation is an anti-"pay-to-play" measure, intended to avoid the creation of a [[conflict of interest]], or the appearance of a conflict of interest, as Goldman Sachs has business in managing state [[pension fund]]s and municipal debt. In 2016, Goldman Sachs's compliance department barred the firm's 450 partners (its most senior employees) from making donations to state or local officials, as well as "any federal candidate who is a sitting state or local official". One effect of this rule was to bar Goldman partners from directly donating to [[Donald Trump]]'s [[Donald Trump 2016 presidential campaign|presidential campaign]], since Trump's running mate, [[Mike Pence]], was the sitting [[governor of Indiana]]. Donations to [[Hillary Clinton]]'s [[Hillary Clinton 2016 presidential campaign|presidential campaign]] were not barred by the policy, since neither Clinton nor her running mate [[Tim Kaine]] was a sitting state or local official. In the 2016 election cycle, Goldman employees were reported ({{as of|2016|September|lc=y}}) to have donated $371,245 to the [[Republican National Committee]] and $301,119 to the [[Hillary Clinton 2016 presidential campaign|Hillary Clinton presidential campaign]]. ==Management== ===Officers and directors=== Notable current non-employee members of the [[board of directors]] of the company are [[M.
